div.head: To the Courteous, and woorthie minded Gentleman, Maister George Gifford, as also to the vertuous Gentlewoman his wife: a happy and continuall societie of mutuall looue, with all gratious benefits, to be plentifully plant • d betweene them.
div.p:
FOure thinges▪ (Right courteous) the Philosophers highly 〈◊〉 to haue continuall residence in a noble and a gentle minde; a courage to repell the encroching enemy; a ha •• to consider a loyall free • d:
a hande to rewarde the gif •• of the simple: and clemencie to accept and pardon a well meaning minde.

All these by nature spreading gallantly in you bothe, vrged me to commend this little motion of great goodwill, vnder your wunted fauoure and freendly patronage: Knowing that the hardest Adamant, dipped in the blood of a Lion or a Goate, will mollifie from the hardnes it containeth by nature. Euen so the simplest woorke, presented to persons of so great wisdome and grauitie, will be construed according to the good meaning of the man, and not after the vnlearned phrase of the simple matter.

Thus remayning, bothe in dutie and desire, the moste affectioned
to your continuall well fare: I wish as great content to you in the reading, as it hath beene bothe paine and pleasure to me in the writing.

closer.signed: Yours, bothe now and alwayes. A. M.
